comments.body:
So in a Fedora 21 setup, I do get a packaged file from the repositories.

```
[vagrant@kubernetes-master ~]$ cat /usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service
[Unit]
Description=Docker Application Container Engine
Documentation=http://docs.docker.com
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=notify
EnvironmentFile=-/etc/sysconfig/docker
EnvironmentFile=-/etc/sysconfig/docker-storage
EnvironmentFile=-/etc/sysconfig/docker-network
Environment=GOTRACEBACK=crash
ExecStart=/usr/bin/docker -d \
          $OPTIONS \
          $DOCKER_STORAGE_OPTIONS \
          $DOCKER_NETWORK_OPTIONS \
          $INSECURE_REGISTRY
LimitNOFILE=1048576
LimitNPROC=1048576
LimitCORE=infinity
MountFlags=slave

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

Can we align your sample file with the one provided by that distro?
I'd be happy to, except where did this come from (i.e. is it GPL?)

@justinsb - So the behavior differences are not major concern right now for the Vagrant setup, I think I am fine if you keep the file you have now.  I am not running with any custom storage solutions now, so I don't think I need the ease of the separate environment files.

@justinsb - or better, in case someone does a yum update, can you only write this file if the os_family is not RedHat since the RedHat packaged docker does include a service file?  so basically, this is the only os specific issue among systemd distros right now.

I think that's a good idea; definitely at this stage we want to minimizing changes!

I think this whole thing is in the `else` block of `{% if grains.os_family == 'RedHat' %}`, so I think we get the (more complete) docker service as provided by the OS on RedHat, and we only have to install our own on non-Redhat systemd (i.e. Jessie and Vervet).
